object.name: OVN Troubleshooting
object.snippet:
Identifying running services on each node
# pcs status
Container bundle set: ovn-dbs-bundle [undercloud-0.ctlplane.redhat.local:8787/rh-osbs/rhosp16-openstack-ovn-northd:pcmklatest]
   ovn-dbs-bundle-0     (ocf::ovn:ovndb-servers):       Master controller-0
   ovn-dbs-bundle-1 â€¦

text.text: OpenFlow tables can be obtained by Ingress Table + 8 or Egress Table + 40
For a detailed explanation of the OVN (logical) tables you can check the manpage of ovn-northd.
DHCP

Unlike in ML2/OVS, OVN serves DHCP locally in the compute nodes. The DHCP requests are sent to ovn-controller and replied according to the DB contents. When a VM starts on a hypervisor, ovn-controller will install flows in table 20 with a controller action
We can find the right DHCP_Options row in the NB database (Neutron inserts this every time a subnet is created):

()[root@controller-1 /]# ovn-nbctl find DHCP_Options external_ids:subnet_id=c35226d1-0984-4887-ad38-750c04fba350

_uuid               : a825bbdb-3de2-4cd2-aa75-11951894c087
cidr                : "192.168.30.0/24"
external_ids        : {"neutron:revision_number"="0", subnet_id="c35226d1-0984-4887-ad38-750c04fba350"}
options             : {classless_static_route="{169.254.169.254/32,192.168.30.2, 0.0.0.0/0,192.168.30.1}", dns_server="{172.16.0.1, 10.0.0.1}", lease_time="43200", mtu="1442", router="192.168.30.1", server_id="192.168.30.1", server_mac="fa:16:3e:95:ec:6f"}


169.254.169.254/32,192.168.30.2 -> static route for Metadata service
0.0.0.0/0,192.168.30.1 -> Default gateway

()[root@controller-1 /]# ovn-sbctl find logical_flow external_ids:stage-name=ls_in_dhcp_options
_uuid               : 542caa72-21de-495f-8ac3-d5a44190ef5a
actions             : "reg0[3] = put_dhcp_opts(offerip = 192.168.30.84, classless_static_route = {169.254.169.254/32,192.168.30.2, 0.0.0.0/0,192.168.30.1}, dns_server = {172.16.0.1, 10.0.0.1}, lease_time = 43200, mtu = 1442, netmask = 255.255.255.0, router = 192.168.30.1, server_id = 192.168.30.1); next;"
external_ids        : {source="ovn-northd.c:5413", stage-name=ls_in_dhcp_options}
logical_datapath    : 663fc9ef-edb9-4171-9526-f46264ef091c
match               : "inport == \"b9fa396c-e2ce-4b67-9d21-05cf126ccabf\" && eth.src == fa:16:3e:98:8e:ab && ip4.src == 0.0.0.0 && ip4.dst == 255.255.255.255 && udp.src == 68 && udp.dst == 67"
pipeline            : ingress
priority            : 100
table_id            : 12
In compute-0 we should be able to see the flow in table 20 (12+8):

()[root@compute-0 /]# ovs-ofctl dump-flows br-int |grep 542caa72
 cookie=0x542caa72, duration=715849.154s, table=20, n_packets=0, n_bytes=0, idle_age=65534, hard_age=65534, priority=100,udp,reg14=0x3,metadata=0x2,dl_src=fa:16:3e:98:8e:ab,nw_src=0.0.0.0,nw_dst=255.255.255.255,tp_src=68,tp_dst=67 actions=controller(userdata=00.00.00.02.00.00.00.00.00.01.de.10.00.00.00.63.c0.a8.1e.54.79.0e.20.a9.fe.a9.fe.c0.a8.1e.02.00.c0.a8.1e.01.06.08.ac.10.00.01.0a.00.00.01.33.04.00.00.a8.c0.1a.02.05.a2.01.04.ff.ff.ff.00.03.04.c0.a8.1e.01.36.04.c0.a8.1e.01,pause),resubmit(,21)
OVN Troubleshooting
Identifying running services on each node

# pcs status
Container bundle set: ovn-dbs-bundle [undercloud-0.ctlplane.redhat.local:8787/rh-osbs/rhosp16-openstack-ovn-northd:pcmklatest]
   ovn-dbs-bundle-0     (ocf::ovn:ovndb-servers):       Master controller-0
   ovn-dbs-bundle-1     (ocf::ovn:ovndb-servers):       Slave controller-1
   ovn-dbs-bundle-2     (ocf::ovn:ovndb-servers):       Slave controller-2
 ip-172.17.1.42 (ocf::heartbeat:IPaddr2):       Started controller-0

# pcs resource show ovn-dbs-bundle
  Resource: ovndb_servers (class=ocf provider=ovn type=ovndb-servers)
   Attributes: inactive_probe_interval=180000 manage_northd=yes master_ip=172.17.1.42 nb_master_port=6641 sb_master_port=6642
   Meta Attrs: container-attribute-target=host notify=true
   Operations: demote interval=0s timeout=50s (ovndb_servers-demote-interval-0s)
               monitor interval=10s role=Master timeout=60s (ovndb_servers-monitor-interval-10s)
               monitor interval=30s role=Slave timeout=60s (ovndb_servers-monitor-interval-30s)
               notify interval=0s timeout=20s (ovndb_servers-notify-interval-0s)
               promote interval=0s timeout=50s (ovndb_servers-promote-interval-0s)
               start interval=0s timeout=200s (ovndb_servers-start-interval-0s)
               stop interval=0s timeout=200s (ovndb_servers-stop-interval-0s)
Executing OVN commands in the cluster
Determining which node runs the OVN DBs as master

$ ansible -b -i /usr/bin/tripleo-ansible-inventory  -m shell -a "pcs status | grep ovn-dbs-bundle | grep Master" controller-2
controller-0 | CHANGED | rc=0 >>
   ovn-dbs-bundle-0     (ocf::ovn:ovndb-servers):       Master controller-0
From the ovn-dbs-bundle-podman-0  container running in this node, we can execute R/W operations into the NB and SB databases

[root@controller-0 ~]# podman exec -it ovn-dbs-bundle-podman-0 bash
()[root@controller-0 /]# ovn-nbctl ls-add ovn_test_lswitch
()[root@controller-0 /]# ovn-nbctl ls-list | grep ovn_test_lswitch
f830fc06-3c47-4acf-8912-4c7945c744a3 (ovn_test_lswitch)
()[root@controller-0 /]# ovn-nbctl ls-del ovn_test_lswitch
()[root@controller-0 /]# ovn-nbctl ls-list | grep -c ovn_test_lswitch
0
Executing OVN commands in the cluster
We can also run commands from a non-master node but we need the VIP of the service

[root@controller-2 ~]# ovs-vsctl get Open_Vswitch . external_ids:ovn-remote | cut -d':' -f 2
172.17.1.42
We will now use the above IP address to run commands inside the ovn-dbs-bundle-podman-xcontainer

()[root@controller-2 /]# ovn-nbctl --db="tcp:172.17.1.42:6641" ls-add ovn_test_lswitch
()[root@controller-2 /]# ovn-nbctl --db="tcp:172.17.1.42:6641" ls-del ovn_test_lswitch
()[root@controller-2 /]# ovn-sbctl --db="tcp:172.17.1.42:6642" chassis-add ovn_test_chassis geneve 127.0.0.1
()[root@controller-2 /]# ovn-sbctl --db="tcp:172.17.1.42:6642" chassis-del ovn_test_chassis
By default,  TCP port 6641 and 6642 are used for OVN NB and SB respectively
OVN DBs summary
By checking the NB database we can see the logical elements

()[root@controller-0 /]# ovn-nbctl show
[...]
router 1ec0773e-3337-47c1-9795-06ac8c7ecabb (neutron-efed639f-560e-442b-8d22-f0d3911205df) (aka router1)
    port lrp-8506ae24-9471-4f0f-974a-bbd3b1d3b969  <- private1 subnet interface
        mac: "fa:16:3e:ee:35:9b"
        networks: ["192.168.30.1/24"]            
    port lrp-93b49ece-2dbc-4fcc-84cb-e7afd482a12e  <- public subnet interface
        mac: "fa:16:3e:8c:77:99"
        networks: ["10.0.0.116/24"]  
        gateway chassis: [43d98571-ccd6-48ce-bf4f-08f24aeed522 0444b1f1-e9a9-4a73-ba78-997c87e61795 fe8f9887-27ef-4724-8cfc-50ec6e3d4a98]
    port lrp-a1ce88e2-5698-44e7-9651-daa7fdca6c30  <- private2 subnet interface
        mac: "fa:16:3e:1b:4c:16"
        networks: ["192.168.40.1/24"]
    nat 183cb3c4-2f56-44e0-a6f3-475deb1a7c06       <- Floating IP
        external ip: "10.0.0.173"
        logical ip: "192.168.40.220"
        type: "dnat_and_snat"   
    nat 3c0add97-0d5f-4d1d-8ffc-7899e8ba8ab1       <- SNAT rule for private1 subnet
        external ip: "10.0.0.116"
        logical ip: "192.168.30.0/24"
        type: "snat"
    nat 43dc9430-b6e6-48aa-ad8a-8792e0a78d86       <- Floating IP
        external ip: "10.0.0.172"
        logical ip: "192.168.40.166"
        type: "dnat_and_snat"
    nat 92ce7038-6563-44f7-a0c2-0deaea2338ce       <- Floating IP
        external ip: "10.0.0.170"
        logical ip: "192.168.30.84"
        type: "dnat_and_snat"
    nat d0a87517-b7a3-4a6c-9307-9b178307fca0      <- SNAT rule for private2 subnet
        external ip: "10.0.0.116"
        logical ip: "192.168.40.0/24"
        type: "snat"
By checking the SB database we can tell where the logical elements are physically located

()[root@controller-0 /]# ovn-sbctl show

Chassis "49017047-3787-4191-9730-fddfc8380a15"
    hostname: "compute-0.redhat.local"
    Encap geneve
        ip: "172.17.2.93"
        options: {csum="true"}
    Port_Binding "f4ada4a0-387f-428a-b1b8-b484d32aa795"  <- private2_vm1 in compute-0   
    Port_Binding "b9fa396c-e2ce-4b67-9d21-05cf126ccabf"  <- private1_vm1 in compute-0
Chassis "fc6db124-5639-4b22-84c1-aafe472b40f7"
    hostname: "compute-1.redhat.local"
    Encap geneve
        ip: "172.17.2.92"
        options: {csum="true"}
    Port_Binding "b34b73d9-0002-477b-9a92-392d3e2cb15c"  <- private1_vm2 in compute-1
    Port_Binding "4a406363-ca36-4a00-bd78-8f21cd50dc32"  <- private2_vm2 in compute-1
Chassis "43d98571-ccd6-48ce-bf4f-08f24aeed522"
    hostname: "controller-2.redhat.local"
    Encap geneve
        ip: "172.17.2.10"
        options: {csum="true"}
    Port_Binding "cr-lrp-93b49ece-2dbc-4fcc-84cb-e7afd482a12e"      <- Gateway port in controller-2 (SNAT traffic)

[...]
Neutron SGR â†’ ACL â†’ Logical Flow â†’ OpenFlow
We can trace a Neutron Security Group Rule to the OpenFlow(s) installed in the hypervisor by inspecting the ACL (NB) and the associated Logical Flows (SB) objects

()[root@controller-2 /]# ovn-sbctl find Logical_Flow external_ids:stage-hint=59ec7790
_uuid               : bcedeade-d2fb-48c4-95b4-8a0f206fb94f
actions             : "next;"
external_ids        : {source="northd.c:6108", stage-hint="59ec7790", stage-name=ls_out_acl}
logical_datapath    : 1ca12790-5019-4488-af4c-911b1f998b98
match               : "reg0[8] == 1 && (outport == @pg_a7150ec3_60ec_440f_950a_0ef3037bfdc6 && ip4 && ip4.src == 192.168.13.240/30 && tcp && tcp.dst == 9999)"
pipeline            : egress
priority            : 2002
table_id            : 4
hash                : 0

_uuid               : 8a4a7cf1-5082-4cd8-8182-77d0770d9050
actions             : "reg0[1] = 1; next;"
external_ids        : {source="northd.c:6084", stage-hint="59ec7790", stage-name=ls_out_acl}
logical_datapath    : 1ca12790-5019-4488-af4c-911b1f998b98
match               : "reg0[7] == 1 && (outport == @pg_a7150ec3_60ec_440f_950a_0ef3037bfdc6 && ip4 && ip4.src == 192.168.13.240/30 && tcp && tcp.dst == 9999)"
pipeline            : egress
priority            : 2002
table_id            : 4
hash                : 0
Now in any of our compute nodes we can verify the OpenFlow(s) associated to this Security Group rule

[root@compute-0 ~]# for i in bcedeade 8a4a7cf1 ;do ovs-ofctl dump-flows br-int |grep $i; done
 cookie=0xbcedeade, duration=139729.046s, table=44, n_packets=0, n_bytes=0, idle_age=65534, hard_age=65534, priority=2002,tcp,reg0=0x100/0x100,reg15=0x3,metadata=0x8,nw_src=192.168.13.240/30,tp_dst=9999 actions=resubmit(,45)
 cookie=0x8a4a7cf1, duration=139729.083s, table=44, n_packets=0, n_bytes=0, idle_age=65534, hard_age=65534, priority=2002,tcp,reg0=0x80/0x80,reg15=0x3,metadata=0x8,nw_src=192.168.13.240/30,tp_dst=9999 actions=load:0x1->NXM_NX_XXREG0[97],resubmit(,45)

[root@compute-0 ~]# ovs-ofctl dump-flows br-int table=65 |grep 'reg15=0x3,metadata=0x8'

[root@compute-0 ~]# ovs-ofctl show br-int
reg15=0x3,metadata=0x8 : csl-log-redhat-0 (192.168.13.109) bound to compute-0
ovn-trace
ovn-trace works by reading the Logical_Flow and other tables from the OVN Southbound  database.
It simulates a packetâ€™s path through logical networks by repeatedly looking it up in the logical flow table, following the entire tree of possibilities.
ovn-trace simulates only the OVN logical network. It does not simulate the physical elements on which the logical network  is  layered.
If the ovn-trace output looks correct for a given network flow but it doesnâ€™t work in reality, we need to troubleshoot further into the physical layout.

When run with the --ovs option, ovn-trace will try to pull the associated OVS flows installed in the bridge by ovn-controller printing the OpenFlow rules for every stage. This will require to run the command in the hypervisor weâ€™re interested.
Letâ€™s explore ICMP traffic between two guests

()[root@compute-0 /]# ovn-trace --db="tcp:172.17.1.42:6642" --ovs --friendly-names --ct=new private2  'inport == "4a406363-ca36-4a00-bd78-8f21cd50dc32" && eth.src == fa:16:3e:5d:87:18 && eth.dst == fa:16:3e:49:85:94 && ip4.src == 192.168.40.220 && ip4.dst == 192.168.40.166 && ip.ttl == 64 && icmp4.type == 8'

#icmp,reg14=0x3,vlan_tci=0x0000,dl_src=fa:16:3e:98:8e:ab,dl_dst=fa:16:3e:aa:5d:92,nw_src=192.168.30.84,nw_dst=192.168.30.159,nw_tos=0,nw_ecn=0,nw_ttl=64,icmp_type=8,icmp_code=0

ingress(dp="private2", inport="private2_vm2")
---------------------------------------------
[...]
 4. ls_out_acl (ovn-northd.c:4549): !ct.new && ct.est && !ct.rpl && ct_label.blocked == 0 && (outport == @pg_f3c36401_fbe6_4df5_8973_8b701e986fa6 && ip4 && ip4.src == 0.0.0.0/0 && icmp4), priority 2002, uuid f3db6f43
    cookie=0xf3db6f43, duration=705499.023s, table=44, n_packets=130, n_bytes=12740, priority=2002,ct_state=-new+est-rpl+trk,ct_label=0/0x1,icmp,reg15=0x3,metadata=0x3 actions=resubmit(,45)
    next;

[...]
 9. ls_out_port_sec_l2 (ovn-northd.c:4081): outport == "private2_vm1" && eth.dst == {fa:16:3e:49:85:94}, priority 50, uuid 060cf739
    cookie=0x60cf739, duration=705499.025s, table=49, n_packets=4094, n_bytes=428295, priority=50,reg15=0x3,metadata=0x3,dl_dst=fa:16:3e:49:85:94 actions=resubmit(,64)
    output;
    /* output to "private2_vm1", type "" */
Physical flows
Letâ€™s explore an ICMP packet delivered to private2_vm2 on its compute node.

We will ping between two guests and we expect the packet being delivered on the right tap interface. Weâ€™ll monitor the flow and assert that it is being hit by checking the n_packets field on table 65.
In the manpage of ovn-architecture you can see that table 65 performs the translation between logical port to a physical port and the traffic is output in that table**

[root@compute-0 /]# ovs-ofctl show br-int|grep tapf4ada4a0
 113(tapf4ada4a0-38): addr:fe:16:3e:49:85:94


[root@compute-0 ~]# watch -d -n1 "ovs-ofctl dump-flows br-int table=65 | grep 'output:113'"
cookie=0x0, duration=706084.536s, table=65, n_packets=4111, n_bytes=429849, idle_age=11, hard_age=65534, priority=100,reg15=0x3,metadata=0x3 actions=output:113
